revision.comment: +{{[[Template:Authority control|Authority control]]}} (3 sources from Wikidata), [[WP:GenFixes]] on, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox architect | name = Henrik Valeur | image = Henrik Valeur in Delhi, 2014.jpg | image_size = | caption = Henrik Valeur in [[Delhi]], 2014 | nationality = Danish | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1966|10|13|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Kunstakademiets Arkitektskole|Royal Academy of Fine Arts, School of Architecture]], [[:es:Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Barcelona|Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Barcelona]] | practice = | significant_buildings= | significant_projects = Co-evolution | significant_design = | awards = [[Venice Biennale of Architecture|Golden Lion]] (2006) }} '''Henrik Bjørn Valeur''' ({{IPA-fr|valœʁ}}; born 13 October 1966) is a Danish architect-urbanist, founder and creative director of UiD (Denmark) and UiD Shanghai Co., Ltd (China), curator of ''CO-EVOLUTION: Danish/Chinese Collaboration on Sustainable Urban Development in China'', which was awarded the Golden Lion at the [[Venice Biennale of Architecture]] in 2006, and author of the book [[India: the Urban Transition|''India: the Urban Transition - a Case Study of Development Urbanism'']] (2014), which is based on his experiences teaching, researching and practicing in India.Richa Sharma. ''Development Urbanism, Issues and possibilities: In Conversation with Henrik Valeur'', Tekton, Vol. 2, Issue 1, March 2015 (pp.94-109), ISSN 2349-6282. ==Early life== Henrik Valeur was born in [[Denmark]] in 1966 to visual artist Mogens Valeur and fashion designer Birgitte Valeur. His grandfathers were both civil engineers.Niveditha Ravikumar. [http://www.zingyhomes.com/expert-interview/architect-henrik-valeur-urbanist-interview/ ''Interview: In Conversation with Architect and Urbanist Henrik Valeur''], Zingy Homes, Tete-A-Tete with Experts, October 26, 2015. Retrieved on October 27, 2015. He grew up in [[Tibirke]] ([[Tisvilde]]), a small village located to the north of [[Copenhagen]], and studied architecture with [[Enric Miralles]] at [[:es:Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Barcelona|Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura]] in [[Barcelona]] and at the [[Kunstakademiets Arkitektskole|Royal Academy of Fine Arts, School of Architecture]] in Copenhagen, from where he graduated in 1994. He then worked briefly for [[Rem Koolhaas]]’ [[Office for Metropolitan Architecture]] in [[Rotterdam]].[http://furesoe.lokalavisen.dk/arkitektur-og-procestaenkning-i-skovhuset-/20071120/artikler/711200494 ''Arkitektur og procestænkning i Skovhuset''], Furesø Avis, November 20, 2007 (in Danish). Retrieved on September 18, 2015. ==Career== ===Denmark, Sweden=== In 1995 Henrik Valeur started out on his own making competition entries of which a few were awarded, including a proposal for a new entrance to [[Copenhagen Zoo]]"Jury’s comment: The small – and rather inaccessible – project resembles an elevated landscape, through which a vigorously formed passage is cut out. The proposal is praised for its artistic nerve." ("Dommerkomiteens bemærkninger: Det lille - og meget vanskeligt tilgængelige - projekt har karakter af et hævet landskabeligt terræn, hvorigennem der skæres en stærkt formet passage. Forslaget fremhæves for sin kunstneriske nerve.") [[:dk:Arkitekten|Arkitekten]] no. 17, Konkurrencehæfte 48 (p.12), 1996, ISSN 0004-198X (in Danish). and for a new university on [[Amager]] (U97),"Jury’s comment [excerpts]: With its numerous layers of identity and use the overall structure can be seen as a place where dialogue and concentration meet. [...] As a whole, this entry can be seen as a contribution to the discussion of the university of the future and ways in which planning can actively intervene in a building project which is to be developed over an extended period of time." ("Juryens bemærkninger [uddrag]: Den overordnede bygningskrop med sine mange identitets- og brugslag kan ses som et sted, hvor dialog og koncentration mødes. [...] Som helhed kan forslaget ses som et indlæg i diskussionen om Fremtidens Universitet og om, hvordan planlægningen kan gribe mere aktivt ind i et byggeri, som skal udvikles over lang tid.") [[:dk:Arkitekten|Arkitekten]] no. 5, 1998 (p.19), ISSN 0004-198X (in Danish). following which, in 1997, he founded UiD, a networking urban consultancy. In 1999 he was invited to present his work at Arkitekturgalleriet, an exhibition venue for young architects at the [[Danish Architecture Centre]]. He included in the exhibition, entitled ''‘99'' but sometimes wrongly referred to as ''UiD/Henrik Valeur'', not only his own work but the works of other architects,{{Ref_label|I|i|none}} as well as material that is not commonly seen in architecture exhibitions. Architectural projects were not presented as unique, solitary pieces, but were mixed with commercials, news pieces, slogans and snap shots.Henrik Valeur (ed.). ''’99'', Architectural Publisher B, 1999, {{ISBN|87-90668-14-6}}. The Danish architecture critic [[:dk:Allan de Waal|Allan de Waal]] commented:
“These are radical attempts at a new architectural practice, but almost de-illuminated. At first sight the quotations out of context or the mischievous clippings on the walls critically turn their back on the subject of architecture, away from any architectural core. But it is there! Floating somewhere in between text fragments, photos [...]”."Dennegang er det radikale tilløb til en ny arkitektonisk praksis, men nærmest de-illumineret. For de løsrevne citater eller drilagtige annonceklip på væggene viser i første omgang kritisk væk fra emnet bygningskunst, og ikke umiddelbart ind mod en arkitektonisk kerne. Men den er dér! svævende et sted mellem tekststumper, fotos [...]" Allan de Waal. [http://www.information.dk/27947 ''Alt eller intet''], [[Dagbladet Information|Information]], February 19, 1999 (in Danish). Retrieved on September 16, 2015.
With Swedish architect and comedian [[:sv:Fredrik Fritzson|Fredrik Fritzson]], he initiated CoMa in 2001 – a research project about the newly formed [[Øresund Region]], centered on the cities of [[Copenhagen]] and [[Malmö]], hence the name CoMa, and the urban regions of [[Los Angeles]] and [[Pearl River Delta]]/[[Hong Kong]]. The project was based on a “diagnosis of society as a [[Multiculturalism|multicultural]] society. [T]his diagnosis becomes the frame for conceiving a new regional strategy that crosses the national borders of Denmark and [[Sweden]], using urbanism as an integrating force”.Christian Borch. ''Regional Urbanism'', in ''Futures of Cities'' (p.63), The Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts, School of Architecture Publishers, 2008, {{ISBN|978-87-87136-81-5}}. CoMa was exhibited, in the format of a [[multimedia]] installation, at Form/Design Center in Malmö in 2002Lars Lönroth. ''Konstreportage om multimedia-utställningen "Region Coma" på Form Design Center i Malmö'', [[Sveriges Radio]] Program 1, April 19, 2002 (in Swedish). and at the [[Danish Architecture Centre]] in Copenhagen in 2004.[https://realdania.dk/nyheder/seneste-nyt/nyheder-uden-projekt-2004/chech-in-%C3%B8resund-260304 ''CHECK-IN Øresund - ny udstilling på Dansk Arkitektur Center''], Realdania, March 26, 2004 (in Danish). Retrieved on April 18, 2018. In addition, the team organized a conference about the Øresund RegionMaria Hellström. [http://www.dn.se/arkiv/kultur/nedslag-dansk-arkitektur-center-en-gryende-dialog-svenskdansk-grupp-vill ''En gryende dialog. Svensk-dansk grupp vill ge Öresundsregionen en egen, tydlig prägel''], [[Dagens Nyheter]], May 2, 2004 (in Swedish). Retrieved on September 16, 2015. and contributed a sound installation to an international group exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art in [[Roskilde]].Yrr Jónasdóttir. [http://uid.dk/files/undercover_synpunkt.pdf ''Ljud som samtidskonst i det offentliga rummet''], Synspunkt, no. 5, May 2003 (in Swedish). Retrieved on September 16, 2015. For the development of [[Trekroner]] East in Roskilde (2002–03), Henrik Valeur organized a workshop with groups of young architects,{{Ref_label|II|ii|none}} artists{{Ref_label|III|iii|none}} and representatives of various interest groups, the municipality, local citizens and experts, who worked together to design the landscape of this new part of the city - prior to the design of the buildings,Jan Bille and Henrik Valeur. ''Bedre byrum i Roskilde – 5 dages debat om byudvikling'', Stads- og havneingeniøren no. 2, 2003 (pp.41-43), ISSN 1902-2654 (in Danish). thus making it a practical example of [[landscape urbanism]] and of a [[Participatory planning|participatory]] and [[Collaboration|collaborative]] planning process.Birgitte Kleis. ''Trekroner Øst – en anderledes byudviklingsproces'', [[:dk:Arkitekten|Arkitekten]] no. 30, 2002 (pp.12-13), ISSN 0004-198X (in Danish). During the early 2000s, Henrik Valeur and Fredrik Fritzon developed a series of planning tools intended to make planning processes flexible and inclusive.Pernille Stensgaard. ''Så er der opbrud!'', Byplan Nyt no. 3 2005 (pp.6-9), ISSN 1602-9038 (in Danish). These tools, which include the 1:1 Sketch Model, the 4D+ Model and the Change Design Model, were demonstrated and discussed at a fair-like idea shop, which they organized for the ''6th European Biennal of Towns and Town Planning'' in Copenhagen in 2005.''Process Planning: Parallel Processing'', [[:dk:Arkitekten|Arkitekten]] no. 7, 2005 (pp.24-25), ISSN 0004-198X (in Danish). Several young Danish and Swedish architecture offices{{Ref_label|IV|iv|none}} participated in the idea shop, which was entitled ''A New Future for Planning – Young Architects Show the Way!''Henrik Valeur (ed.). ''A New Future For Planning'', Architectural Publisher B, 2005, {{ISBN|87-990146-5-3}}. Henrik Valeur and Fredrik Fritzson's ideas of planning were implemented in the development of [[Musicon]] in Roskilde, for which they made the [[structure plan]] and the process manual, based on a scenario game and [[Role-playing game|role play]] with local stakeholders.[http://uid.dk/urbanism.html ''Urbanism''], UiD. Retrieved on November 26, 2015. [[Roskilde Municipality]] was awarded the [[Danish Urban Planning Award]] in 2012 for the "exceptionally creative planning" of Musicon.[http://www.byplanlab.dk/byplanprisen/2012 ''Vinder af Byplanprisen 2012''], [[:dk:Dansk Byplanlaboratorium|Dansk Byplanlaboratorium]], October 5, 2012 (in Danish). Retrieved on February 3, 2016. ===China=== Henrik Valeur was appointed [[curator]] of the Danish Pavilion at the [[Venice Biennale of Architecture]] in 2006.Rune Huvendick Jensen. [http://www.dac.dk/da/service-sider/nyheder/2006/september/biennale-fremtiden-foregaar-i-kina/ ''Biennale: Fremtiden foregår i Kina''], [[Danish Architecture Centre]], September 7, 2006 (in Danish). Retrieved on September 17, 2015. He traveled to [[China]] where he met with universities and city administrations in several of the biggest Chinese cities.Bert de Muynck. [http://movingcities.org/interviews/henrik-valeur_domuschina/ ''An interview with Henrik Valeur''], [[Domus (magazine)|Domus]] China, no. 4, 2007, ISSN 0012-5377. Retrieved on September 16, 2015. Based on the conversations he had with people there he conceived the project ''CO-EVOLUTION - Danish/Chinese Collaboration on Sustainable Urban Development in China''Szilágyi Gábor. [http://epiteszforum.hu/co-evolution-a-kina-jelenseg-a-velencei-dan-pavilonban ''Co-evolution / a kína-jelenség a velencei dán pavilonban''], Epiteszforum, October 10, 2006 (in Hungarian). Retrieved on September 17, 2015.Torben Weirup. [http://www.b.dk/kultur/danske-arkitekter-ud-af-osteklokken ''Danske arkitekter ud af osteklokken''], [[Berlingske]], September 6, 2006 (in Danish). Retrieved on November 6, 2015. in which young professional Danish architects{{Ref_label|V|v|none}} and architecture students would work together with professors and students from leading Chinese universities{{Ref_label|VI|vi|none}} in the cities of [[Beijing]], [[Chongqing]], [[Shanghai]] and [[Xi’an]].Anette Sørensen. ''Ikke et designkorstog til Kina'', Danske Ark Byg no. 8, 2006 (pp.36-37), ISSN 0908-1690 (in Danish). The curator and his team{{Ref_label|VII|vii|none}} wrapped the exterior of the Danish Pavilion in a green scaffolding, often seen on Chinese construction sites, and conducted a research project on problems and possibilities related to the processes of rapid [[urbanization in China]], which constituted the background story of the exhibition, literally in the format of billboards mounted on the interior walls of the pavilion, with the project proposals developed by the four teams placed as free-standing installations in space.Finn Selmer. ''High-speed Urbanism'', [[:dk:Arkitekten|Arkitekten]] no. 12, 2006 (pp. 68-71), ISSN 0004-198X (in Danish). ''CO-EVOLUTION'' was awarded the Golden Lion for Best National Participation[http://www.labiennale.org/en/architecture/history/10.html ''The 10th International Architecture Exhibition''], la Biennale di Venezia. Retrieved on September 16, 2015. by the jury of the [[10th International Architecture Exhibition]], [[Richard Sennett]] (President), Amyn Aga Khan, [[Antony Gormley]] and [[Zaha Hadid]], who said:
"We salute the creativity, intelligence, and generosity of the Danish pavilion".[http://www.gat.st/news/10th-international-architecture-exhibition-official-awards ''10th International Architecture Exhibition: Official Awards''], Architektur Steiermark. Retrieved on November 6, 2015.
Henrik Valeur was himself a member of the jury for the 7th [[International Architecture Biennale in São Paulo]], [[Brazil]], in 2007.Kjersti Wikstrøm. [http://dacisaopaulo.blogspot.dk/2007/11/second-largest-city-in-world.html ''The second largest city in the world''], [[Danish Architecture Centre]], November 13, 2007. Retrieved on September 17, 2015. That year he also founded UiD Shanghai Co., Ltd in China and was the co-curator, with Professor Pan Haixiao of [[Tongji University]], of the exhibition ''Harmonious City'',Henrik Valeur (ed.). ''The Harmonious City'', Danish Architecture Centre, 2007, {{ISBN|87-90668-64-2}} (in Chinese). which included examples of Danish experiences with sustainable urban developmentWang Yanlin. [http://www.shanghaidaily.com/news2007/20070926/332629 ''Global wisdom can craft solutions to urban woes''], [[Shanghai Daily]], September 26, 2007. Retrieved on September 16, 2015. and projects by students from Tongji UniversityFei Lai. [http://www.shanghaidaily.com/news2007/20070821/328152 ''Green means go for sustainable development''], [[Shanghai Daily]], August 21, 2007. Retrieved on September 18, 2015. and was exhibited at [[Shanghai Urban Planning Exhibition Center]].Fei Lai. [http://www.shanghaidaily.com/news2007/20070917/331517 ''Danish and Chinese ideas on the 'Harmonious City''], [[Shanghai Daily]], September 17, 2007. Retrieved on September 16, 2015. Among the projects Henrik Valeur created while living in China was the ''Bicycle Tower'',A.K. Streeter. [http://www.treehugger.com/cars/7-great-solutions-for-safely-parking-city-bikes.html ''7 Great Solutions for Safely Parking City Bikes''], [[TreeHugger]], July 12, 2010. Retrieved on September 16, 2015. a design for vertical bicycle parking developed jointly by UiD in Shanghai and Malmö, and exhibited by the [[Malmö Municipality|City of Malmö]] as part of the Urban Best Practice Area at the [[Expo 2010|2010 World Expo in Shanghai]].Bicycle Parking Book, chapter 1-2 (pp.12-13), Bicycle Parking Book, chapter 3-4 (pp.20-29), and Bicycle Parking Book, chapter 5-6 (pp.90-95), in [http://malmo.se/shanghai2010 ''Urban Everyday Travel''], [[Malmö Municipality|City of Malmö]]. Retrieved on September 16, 2015. ===India=== [[File:Henrik Valeur with Chief Architect of Chandigarh.JPG|thumb|Henrik Valeur in a discussion with the Chief Architect of Chandigarh, Ms. Sumit Kaur, on the Car Free Sector Proposal, at Chief Architect's Office in Sector 9, Chandigarh]] In 2010 Henrik Valeur gave the ''[[Le Corbusier]] Memorial Lecture'' in [[Chandigarh]],[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2011/20110404/ttlife1.htm#2 ''Following Gandhi''], [[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]], Life+Style, April 4, 2011. Retrieved on September 18, 2015. in which he noted that:
“The problem with [[Modern architecture|modernist architecture]] is not only that it tries to erase the past; it also obstructs the future!”Pernille Stensgaard. ''Byer som verdens frelse'', [[Weekendavisen]], January 7, 2011 (p.7), (in Danish).
In the following years he worked with Indian students and researchers, activists and bureaucrats, developers and entrepreneurs,{{Ref_label|VIII|viii|none}} and participated in public discussions about the urban transition of India.[http://www.dac.dk/da/service-sider/nyheder/2011/april/dansk-bidrag-til-byudvikling-i-indien/ ''Dansk bidrag til byudvikling i Indien''], [[Danish Architecture Centre]], April 4, 2011 (in Danish). Retrieved on September 17, 2015. His book [[India: the Urban Transition|''India: the Urban Transition - a Case Study of Development Urbanism'']], which is based on his teaching, researching and practicing, primarily in Chandigargh in [[North India]] and [[Bangalore]] in [[South India]], was published in 2014.[https://www.arkitektforeningen.dk/artikel/nyheder/bog-om-byudvikling-i-indien-af-dansk-arkitekt ''Bog om byudvikling i Indien af dansk arkitekt''], Danish Architects' Association, August 18, 2015 (in Danish). Retrieved on September 17, 2015. "The book contextualises city making as a complex highly political process and contends that it is the Indian city that can truly be the landscape on which the idea of India, with its diversity, flourishes".Mukta Naik. [http://www.shram.org/moreArticle.php?cat=3&id=20150420103225# ''Book Review - India: The Urban Transition- A case study of Development Urbanism''], Urban India Vol. 34, Issue 1, January–June 2014 (pp.235-239), ISSN 0970-9045. Retrieved on September 18, 2015. The Indian architect [[Rahul Mehrotra]], Professor and then Chair of Urban Planning and Design at [[Harvard University]], called the book “an important contribution” because of its “fine grain reading of issues in the Indian city” and its “attempt to connect so many dots to make sense of the moving targets we encounter in Urbanism in India".[http://rmaarchitects.com/2015/09/rahul-mehrotra-on-india-the-urban-transition-by-henrik-valeur/ ''Rahul Mehrotra on India: the Urban Transition by Henrik Valeur''], RMA Architects, September 12, 2015. Retrieved on September 16, 2015. One of the projects featured in the book is a proposal to make one of the sectors of Chandigarh [[Pedestrian zone|car-free]].Padmaparna Ghosh. [http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/sunday-times/deep-focus/These-streets-are-made-for-walking/articleshow/27391410.cms ''These streets are made for walking''], [[Times of India]], December 15, 2013. Retrieved on September 17, 2015. Though initially commissioned by the Chief Architect of Chandigarh for the new master plan of the city, the proposal was not realized despite the fact that the [[Punjab and Haryana High Court]] subsequently directed the City Administration to make one of its sectors car-free.Kuldip Dhiman. [http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/sunday-special/people/carnival-we-ought-to-grow-out-of/114300.html ''Carnival we ought to grow out of''], [[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]], August 2, 2015. Retrieved on September 16, 2015. A project for the businessman and environmentalist [[Kamal Meattle]] uses [[natural ventilation]] and “growing fresh air” with plants in a vertical greenhouse to improve indoor air quality in an office building.Preeti Chopra. [https://networks.h-net.org/node/22055/reviews/99672/chopra-valeur-india-urban-transition-case-study-development ''Review of Valeur, Henrik, India: The Urban Transition - A Case Study of Development''], H-Asia, [[H-Net]] Reviews, December, 2015. Retrieved on February 10, 2016 Other projects include a proposal for ''vertical kitchen gardens'' in a colony of rehabilitated [[slum]] dwellers in Chandigarh, developed in collaboration with a local NGO, and a proposal for [[self-build|self-built]] low-cost ''garden flats'' for current slum dwellers in Bangalore, developed with a local developer.Henrik Valeur. ''[[India: the Urban Transition|India: the Urban Transition - a Case Study of Development Urbanism]]'', Architectural Publisher B, 2014, {{ISBN|978-87-92700-09-4}}. In Chandigarh the lack of open space in the colony led to the idea of placing community kitchen gardens on top of each other. In Bangalore residents would be provided an open frame structure to be filled out by themselves according to individual preferences and possibilities.Cecilie Cronwald. ''Den urbane landsby'', [[Weekendavisen]], Ideer, June 27, 2014 (pp.1-3), (in Danish). The reasoning for both projects, i.e. to provide poor people in urban settings with opportunities to produce their own food and to create their own dwellings respectively, owes a debt to the Indian economist [[Amartya Sen]]’s [[capability approach]]. With experiences from both China and India, Henrik Valeur asks whether India can “use urbanization as a driver of economic, human and social development like China has done?”[http://southasiainstitute.harvard.edu/event/21890/ ''India: the Urban Transition''], Harvard University, South Asia Institute, March 28, 2016. Retrieved on May 31, 2016 ==Concerns== ===Natural environment=== According to Henrik Valeur, city and nature should be mixed. In a feature article in [[Politiken]] (2009) he argued that in response to [[climate change]], i.e. [[extreme weather]], [[sea level rise]] and [[stormwater]] etc., ecology and urbanity must be integrated. But rather than moving the city out into the countryside, as [[Ebenezer Howard]] had proposed with his [[Garden city movement|garden city]] concept more than a hundred years earlier, Henrik Valeur suggested that nature be incorporated in the city both physically, for instance in the form of soil and vegetation that can absorb excess water, and conceptually, in the way we think about cities.Henrik Valeur. [http://politiken.dk/debat/kroniken/ECE766723/kronik-vores-oekologiske-fodspor/ ''Vores økologiske fodspor''], [[Politiken]], August 14, 2009. Retrieved on February 10, 2016 The book ''[[India: the Urban Transition]]'' (2014) provides a number of examples, including the revitalization and integration of an existing system of water canals with a new network of pathways for pedestrians in the city of Bangalore, the replacement of asphalt with natural surfaces, so-called ''green streets'', in the city of Chandigarh and the use of plants and natural ventilation to create fresh air inside an office building, in which the plants are also used as movable space dividers with the interior planning being based on principles of [[self-organization]]. ===Smart city=== While in favor of urban development, as a means of creating development in the so-called "[[Developing country|developing]]" world,“Thus, instead of encouraging people to remain in the rural areas, as development aid generally does, people must be encouraged to move to cities, where living conditions, job opportunities, education and health care can and must be improved.” Henrik Valeur. [[India: the Urban Transition|''India: the Urban Transition – a Case Study of Developmemt Urbanism'']] (p.16), Architectural Publisher B, 2014, {{ISBN|978-87-92700-09-4}}. Henrik Valeur has voiced concern about the concept of [[smart city]] floated by Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]] in India.[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/goa/Concept-of-smart-cities-created-by-IT-companies/articleshow/46448754.cms ''Concept of smart cities created by IT companies''], [[Times of India]], March 4, 2015. Retrieved on September 18, 2015. According to Henrik Valeur the "concerns related to the concept of smart city have to do with the issues of control and surveillance, the risk of corruption, misuse and mismanagement, and the prospect of smart cities becoming exclusive enclaves for the rich". ==Concepts== ===Parallel processing=== In response to the tradition of central control and the associated principle of [[determinism]] in Scandinavian planning, Henrik Valeur, in collaboration with Fredrik Fritzson, developed the concept of ''parallel processing'' in [[urban planning]], which was discussed at the ''6th European Biennal of Towns and Town Planning'' in 2005 and implemented in the development of [[Musicon]] in 2007. “The objective of parallel processing is not only to [[Democratization|democratize]] the planning process, but also to let mutual understanding and inspiration generate results, which are more than the sum of the individual interests.” This should be achieved by “establishing planning processes that engage all of the parties involved throughout the entire sequence”. Rather than involving the various actors and stakeholders one after the other at various stages of the process (a serial process) they should all be involved from the very beginning and be able to interact with each other and with the relevant authorities throughout the process (open-ended planning processes were proposed). To this end, and in order to promote flexibility and experimentation, new planning methods and instruments, such as the 1:1 sketch model, the 4D+ model, the Change Design Model, role plays and scenario games, were introduced along with the use of new [[Information and communications technology|information and communications technologies]]. ===Co-evolution=== In biology, “the term [[coevolution|co-evolution]] is used to describe cases where two (or more) species reciprocally affect each other's evolution”.[http://evolution.berkeley.edu/evolibrary/article/evo_33 ''Understanding evolution'']. [[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley University]]. Retrieved on October 14, 2015. Henrik Valeur introduced the concept of co-evolution in architecture in 2006 as curator of the project ''CO-EVOLUTION: Danish/Chinese Collaboration on Sustainable Urban Development in China'' for which he asked four young architecture offices from Denmark to work together with planners and researchers from four Chinese universities to answer the question: "How can China proceed with its ambitious project to improve living conditions for its population without exhausting the very resources needed to sustain a better life?"[http://free-soil.org/index.php?post_id=715&comment=yes Co-Evolution], Free Soil, November 14, 2007. Retrieved on March 6, 2016 By creating a framework for collaboration between academics and professionals representing two distinct cultures, it was hoped that the exchange of knowledge, ideas and experiences would stimulate “creativity and imagination to set the spark for new visions for sustainable urban development".Henrik Valeur (ed.). ''CO-EVOLUTION: Danish/Chinese Collaboration on Sustainable Urban Development in China'', [[Danish Architecture Centre]], 2006, {{ISBN|87-90668-61-8}}. Henrik Valeur later argued that: "As we become more and more interconnected and interdependent, [[Human development (humanity)|human development]] is no longer a matter of the evolution of individual groups of people but rather a matter of the co-evolution of all people". ===Development urbanism=== In 2010, Henrik Valeur wrote an op-ed in the Danish newspaper [[Dagbladet Information|Information]].Henrik Valeur. [http://www.information.dk/237079 ''Verdens fattige flytter til byen''], [[Dagbladet Information|Information]], June 22, 2010 (in Danish). Retrieved on October 14, 2015. In the English translation of the article the term “development urbanism” appears for the first time.Henrik Valeur. [http://henrikvaleur.dk/files/The_Poor_Are_Moving_To_Town.pdf ''The poor are moving to town'']. Retrieved on October 14, 2015. In the book [[India: the Urban Transition|''India: the Urban Transition - a Case Study of Development Urbanism'']], which can be seen as a "call for action to everyone who wants to make a positive and concrete difference to the urban environments of developing societies", Henrik Valeur describes development urbanism as “a multidisciplinary field that is focused on sustainable urban development as a means of combating [[poverty]] and its related illnesses and of protecting the [[Natural environment|environment]], the [[climate]] and the [[Natural resource|resources]]. It addresses basic human concerns in urban settings, seeing cities not as “dumb” [[machine]]s but rather as sophisticated [[ecology|ecologies]] in which people are adapting to a constantly changing environment”. The concept of development urbanism can be seen as an alternative to the concept of [[smart city]].[http://www.lamakaan.com/events/1957 ''Development urbanism - an alternative to the "smart city" concept''], [[Lamakaan]], February 1, 2015. Retrieved on October 14, 2015.[http://hydlab.in/blog/notes/commentary/reflections-on-henrik-valeurs-talk-on-development-urbanism/ ''Reflections on Henrik Valeur’s Talk on Development Urbanism''], Hyderabad Urban Lab, February 3, 2015. Retrieved on September 18, 2015. Said Henrik Valeur: “There are obviously too many unresolved problems in our cities today, but my point is that many of these problems can be solved by very simple and inexpensive means. Smart technologies are rarely necessary and may, in fact, create more problems than they solve”. ==Works (selected)== ===Articles=== * ''[http://www.epw.in/commentary/alternatives-automobile-indian-city.html Alternatives to the Automobile in the Indian City]'', [[Economic & Political Weekly]], Vol - XLVIII No. 47, November 23, 2013 (author) * ''[http://henrikvaleur.dk/files/The_horrendous_costs_of_motorized_transportation_in_Indian_cities.pdf The horrendous costs of motorized transportation in (Indian) cities]'', The Global Urbanist 26.03.2013 and World Streets 30.03.2013 (author) * ''[http://www.epw.in/web-exclusives/grow-your-own-food.html Grow your own food!]'', [[Economic & Political Weekly]], Vol - XLVII No. 24, June 16, 2012 (co-author) * ''[http://www.information.dk/237079 Verdens fattige flytter til byen]'' ([https://henrikvaleur.wordpress.com/2012/03/12/development-urbanism-2/ ''The poor are moving to town'']), [[Dagbladet Information|Information]], 21 June 2010 (author) * [http://henrikvaleur.dk/files/Er_taettere_byer_mere_baeredygtige.pdf ''Er tættere byer mere bæredygtige?''] (''Are dense cities more sustainable?''), [[:dk:Arkitekten|Arkitekten]], no. 12, 2009 (author) * ''[http://politiken.dk/debat/kroniken/ECE766723/kronik-vores-oekologiske-fodspor/ Vores økologiske fodspor]'' (''Our ecological footprint''), [[Politiken]], 14 August 2009 (author) ===Books=== * [https://www.amazon.com/India-Urban-Transition-Development-Urbanism/dp/8792700098/ref=asap_bc?ie=UTF8 ''India: the Urban Transition''], Architectural Publisher B, 2014, {{ISBN|978-87-92700-09-4}} (author) * [https://www.amazon.com/Co-Evolution-Chinese-Collaboration-Sustainable-Development/dp/8790668618/ref=asap_bc?ie=UTF8 ''CO-EVOLUTION''], Danish Architecture Centre, 2006, {{ISBN|87-90668-61-8}} (editor) * [https://www.amazon.com/New-Future-Planning-Henrik-Valeur/dp/8799014653/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1448444660&sr=8-3&keywords=henrik+valeur ''A NEW FUTURE FOR PLANNING''], Architectural Publisher B, 2005, {{ISBN|87-990146-5-3}} (editor) * [https://www.amazon.com/Uid-Henrik-Valeur-Arkitekturgalleriet-Arkitekturgalleriat/dp/8790668146/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1448445039&sr=8-4&keywords=henrik+valeur '''99''], Architectural Publisher B, 1999, {{ISBN|87-90668-14-6}} (editor) ===Exhibitions=== * ''The Harmonious City'', [[Shanghai Urban Planning Exhibition Center]], China, 2007 (co-curator) * ''[http://www.uid.dk/co-evolution.html CO-EVOLUTION]'', [[Venice Biennale of Architecture]], Italy, 2006; 2nd China International Architectural Biennial in Beijing, China, 2006: Xi’an International Conference of Architecture and Technology, China, 2006; [[Tongji University]], China, 2006; [[Danish Architecture Centre]], Denmark, 2006-2007; [[ARoS Aarhus Kunstmuseum|AROS]], Denmark, 2007; [[KUNSTEN Museum of Modern Art Aalborg|North Jytland Art Museum]], Denmark, 2007; [[International Architecture Biennale in São Paulo]], Brazil, 2007; [[Shanghai Urban Planning Exhibition Center]], China, 2007; [[Cube Gallery]], UK, 2008; [[American Institute of Architects]] New York Center for Architecture, USA, 2008; [[London Festival of Architecture]], UK, 2008 (curator) * ''A New Future for Planning'', the 6th European Biennal of Towns and Town Planning, Denmark, 2005 (co-curator) * ''Check-in Öresund'', the [[Danish Architecture Centre]], Denmark, 2004 (co-curator) * '''99'', Arkitekturgalleriet, the [[Danish Architecture Centre]], 1999 (curator) ===Projects=== * ''Low cost garden flats'', development project, 2013 (principal architect) * ''Self-organizing office space: green spaces'', interior planning project, 2011 (principal architect) * ''Vertical kitchen gardens'', development project, 2010-13 (principal architect) * ''Car-free Sector 19'', master plan project, 2010-13 (principal architect) * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k1dIBkqNLyc&feature=youtu.be ''Bicycle Tower''], design project, 2008 (principal architect) * ''[[Musicon]]'', urban development project, 2007 (lead planning consultant) * ''CO-EVOLUTION: the Collaboration'', documentary film, 2006 (producer) * ''Tensta collective house'', competition entry, 2005 (principal architect) * ''Parallel processing'', urban planning methodology, 2005 (principal architect) * ''Real-time-living'', conceptual project, 2004 (principal architect) * ''Garden flats'', development project, 2003-04 (principal architect) * ''[[Trekroner]] East'', urban planning project, 2002-03 (lead planning consultant) * ''4D+ model'', planning tool, 2002-03 (principal architect) * ''Flex-bo'', competition entry, 1998 (principal architect) * ''U97'', competition entry, 1996-97 (principal architect) * ''ZOO'', competition entry, 1995 (principal architect) ==Awards== * The Golden Lion at the [[10th International Architecture Exhibition]] in Venice, 2006 (curator).[http://www.dac.dk/en/dac-life/exhibitions/2006/co-evolution/about-co-evolution/ ''About CO-EVOLUTION''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120011414/http://www.dac.dk/en/dac-life/exhibitions/2006/co-evolution/about-co-evolution/ |date=2015-11-20 }}, [[Danish Architecture Centre]]. Retrieved on September 16, 2015. * The [[Nykredit Architecture Prize|Nykredit Encouragement Prize]], 2004.[http://www.nykredit.dk/omnykredit/ressourcer/dokumenter/pdf/pres250504.pdf Press release], [[Nykredit]], April 25, 2004 (in Danish). Retrieved on September 16, 2015. ==Notes== {{refbegin|colwidth=20em}} i. {{Note_label|I|i|none}} Participating architects: Alex Wall, Christophe Cornubert, MIKAN, njiric+njiric, [[West 8]] and UiD. ii. {{Note_label|II|ii|none}} Participating architecture offices: Copenhagenoffice, Kollision, Plan B, Plot and UiD. iii. {{Note_label|III|iii|none}} Participating artists: Jonas Maria Schül, Ane Mette Ruge, Kerstin Bergendal, Katja Sander and Åsa Sonjasdotter. iv. {{Note_label|IV|iv|none}} Participating architecture offices: Blankspace, Copenhagenoffice, Effekt, Force4, Mutopia, Nord, Testbedstudio and UiD. v. {{Note_label|V|v|none}} Participating architecture offices: [[Cebra]], [[COBE Architects|Cobe]], Effekt and Transform. vi. {{Note_label|VI|vi|none}} Participating universities: [[Chongqing University]], [[Tongji University]], [[Tsinghua University]] and [[Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology]]. vii. {{Note_label|VII|vii|none}} Team members: Uwe Wütherich, Zhang Meng, Annelie Håkansson, Christoffer Pilgaard, Haydar Al-Khatib, Karin Lindgren, Lea Bolvig and Ma Liang. viii. {{Note_label|VIII|viii|none}} Collaborating institutions: [[Chandigarh College of Architecture]], Eco & Agro Resource Management, Indian Institute of Human Settlement, [[Indian Institute of Science]] (Center for Infrastructure, Sustainable Transportation and Urban Planning), [[Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee]] (Department of Architecture and Planning), Itinerant Permaculture and Shristi Space™. {{refend}} {{Clear}} ==References== revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Use British English|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox person | image = | name = | caption = | birth_name = Hollie Victoria Robertson | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1985|3|21|df=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = winning ''[[Strictly Dance Fever]]'' | occupation = [[dancer]] }} '''Hollie Victoria Robertson''' (born 21 March 1985) is an [[England|English]] dancer who won the second series of the [[BBC One]] dance talent show ''[[Strictly Dance Fever]]'' together with partner [[Darrien Wright]]. In the final they beat [[Darren Bailey]] and [[Lana Williams]].
== Early life ==
Robertson grew up in [[Ludlow]], [[Shropshire]]. Her background is [[gymnastics]] in which she participated from the age of six to thirteen until she [[Spinal disc herniation|slipped a disc]]. She achieved third place at the British Championships in the [[Vault (gymnastics)|vaulting horse]], later getting into [[hip hop dance]]. Robertson names [[Levell Smith Junior]] as her biggest influence.
== Education ==
Robertson took dance classes at In-Steps in Ludlow, where she still teaches hip hop and commercial jazz.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.in-steps.co.uk/teachers.htm |title = Teachers list at In-Step |accessdate = 2007-08-24 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928235310/http://www.in-steps.co.uk/teachers.htm |archivedate = 28 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> From 2005 she attended the Midlands Academy of Dance and Drama in [[Nottingham]] for a two-year course in [[musical theatre]].
== Career before Strictly Dance Fever ==
In 2004, Robertson won choreographer [[Wade Robson]]'s [[MTV]] show, ''Shakedown'', taking the title of best dancer in Europe. In 2005, she was a backing dancer in the video of the single "[[Only U]]" by [[Ashanti (entertainer)|Ashanti]]. She has also danced for [[Rachel Stevens]] and [[McFly]].
== Strictly Dance Fever ==
{{See also|Strictly Dance Fever}}
''Strictly Dance Fever'' is an amateur dance competition broadcast on the BBC, consisting of several rounds of auditions followed by weekly live shows in which one couple is voted off each week until three couples are left for the final live show. Voting is done by professional judges and the viewing public, each making up 50% of the total score. The four judges award scores out of ten, while the public phones in to vote for their favourite. During the weeks of the live shows, the couples live together in a ''Dance Mansion'' where they receive intensive training.
The show is open to non-professional dancers over the age of 18.<ref name="pressfinal"/> Even though Robertson had previously won a similar competition on MTV called ''Shakedown'' and had been awarded the title of best dancer in Europe, she was not a professional dancer and therefore was allowed to enter.
Robertson participated in series two, which was broadcast in the spring of 2006. In that series 80,000 participants applied for the auditions. Over a million telephone votes were cast over the course of the series.<ref name="pressfinal"/>
Robertson auditioned with her boyfriend Bruno. Eventually he was not selected for the live shows and she was partnered with [[Darrien Wright]]. Robertson and Wright won the final on 3 June 2006 beating [[Darren Bailey]] and [[Lana Williams]].
Robertson and Wright received the top score of ten out of ten of all the judges on both their dances in the final.<ref name="pressfinal"/> They performed [[Milonga (dance)|The Milonga]] and a freestyle dance. In an earlier round they had also achieved the highest possible score for one of their dances.
The prize consisted of ₤50,000 for the couple and a contract to dance for one week in the production of ''[[Footloose (musical)|Footloose]]'' on the [[West End theatre|West End]]. Robertson said after winning the final: "I want to put the prize money towards a dance studio so I can teach."<ref name="pressfinal"> {{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2006/06_june/03/fever.shtml |title=Strictly Dance Fever 2006 winning couple crowned |accessdate=2007-09-06 |date=3 June 2006 |publisher=BBC Press Office }} </ref>
=== Dances and scores ===
{| class="wikitable" |+ Dances performed by Robertson and Wright on the second series of ''Strictly Dance Fever''<ref> {{cite web |url = http://strictlydancing.utopian-totality.co.uk/content/view/2193/#7 |title = Scores by week |work = Strictly Dancing |accessdate = 2007-09-08 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071008095419/http://strictlydancing.utopian-totality.co.uk/content/view/2193/#7 |archivedate = 8 October 2007 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> |- ! rowspan = "2" style="background:#ffdead;" |   ! rowspan = "2" style="background:#ffdead;" | Dance ! colspan = "5" style="background:#ffdead;" | Judges scores |- ! style="background:#ffdead;" | Stacey Haynes ! style="background:#ffdead;" | [[Arlene Phillips]] ! style="background:#ffdead;" | [[Wayne Sleep]] ! style="background:#ffdead;" | [[Ben Richards (actor)|Ben Richards]] ! style="background:#ffdead;" | Total |- ! Show 1 | [[Rock and Roll (dance)|Rock and Roll]] || 8 || 8 || 8 || 9 || 33 |- ! Show 2 | [[Argentine tango]] || 6 || 4 || 7 || 5 || 22 |- ! Show 3 | [[Guapacha (dance)|Guapacha]] || 8 || 9 || 8 || 7 || 32 |- ! Show 4 | [[Jitterbug]] || 6 || 7 || 7 || 7 || 27<ref name="bbcweek4"> {{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/strictlydancefever/dancefever/news/2006/05/04/31852.shtml |title=Week Four |publisher=BBC |work=Strictly Dance Fever site |date=4 May 2006 |accessdate=2007-09-08 }} </ref> |- ! Show 5 | [[American Smooth]] || 8 || 10 || 8 || 9 || 35 |- ! rowspan = "2" | Show 6 | [[Milonga (dance)|Milonga]] || 10 || 10 || 10 || 10 || 40 |- | [[Lindy Hop]] || 8 || 7 || 8 || 8 || 31 |- ! rowspan = "2" | Show 7 | [[Hustle (dance)|Hustle]] || n/a || 6 || 9 || 8 || 23 (out of 30) |- | Adagio || n/a || 6 || 6 || 8 || 20 (out of 30) |- ! rowspan = "2" | Final | [[Milonga (dance)|Milonga]] || 10 || 10 || 10 || 10 || 40<ref name="pressfinal"/> |- | Freestyle || 10 || 10 || 10 || 10 || 40<ref name="pressfinal"/> |}
== Career after Strictly Dance Fever ==
As part of their prize, Robertson and Wright won a professional dance contract. This culminated early in July 2006 when, for a week, the pair took to the [[West End theatre|West End]] stage as background dancers in ''[[Footloose (musical)|Footloose]]'' in [[London]]'s [[Novello Theatre]].<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/display?contentId=90067 |title=Interview in Official London Theatre Guide about first night of Footloose |accessdate=2007-08-24 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927203014/http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/display?contentId=90067 |archivedate=27 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} </ref> [[David Essex]] and [[Cheryl Baker]] also starred in the show.
Robertson's career suffered a minor set-back when she was injured after an attack on holiday in Portugal. Regarding this incident she's quoted as saying: "I've never had anything so painful happen to me in my life before. It was horrible, absolutely horrible. [...] Stuff happens to you in life and you just have to get on with it and as long as I don't stop dancing it's ok...I'll be ok."<ref> {{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/shropshire/5264554.stm |title=news story about attack in Portugal on BBC News site |accessdate=2007-08-24 | date=19 August 2006}} </ref>
Robertson is currently appearing in the UK tour of ''[[Fame (musical)|Fame]]''<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.theatre.com/story/id/3006057 |title=theatre.com about Fame |accessdate=2007-08-24 |df=dmy-all }}{{dead link|date=May 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} </ref><ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.uktw.co.uk/dl/page.php?page=details&id=T0705370680 |title = Cast info for Fame at UK Theatre Web |accessdate = 2007-08-24 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927223320/http://www.uktw.co.uk/dl/page.php?page=details&id=T0705370680 |archivedate = 27 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> alongside dance partner Darrien Wright.
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
{{Refbegin}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/strictlydancefever/dancefever/news/2006/04/07/31085.shtml |title=Hollie Roberston profile on the official Strictly Dance Fever website |accessdate=2007-08-24 }} * {{cite web |url=https://dancers.mandy.com/uk |title=Hollie Roberston profile and detailed dancography on dancers.mandy.com |accessdate=2007-08-24 }} {{Refend}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071008143539/http://www.amck.tv/artists2.php?aid=65&category=Dancer Talent portfolio] for Hollie Robertson at the AMCK Management website
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
The '''International Moral Education Congress''' was an international [[academic conference]] held in Europe six times between 1908 and 1934. It convened because of an interest in moral education by many countries beginning a decade before the inaugural event. The movement for moral education had an ardent champion in the [[Ethical movement]].<ref name=1st1908 /> The idea to hold the congress was at the behest of the International Union of Ethical Societies; its greatest proponents were Professor [[Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster]] and [[Gustav Spiller]], the secretary of the Union.<ref name=Sadler1909>{{cite journal|last1=Sadler|first1=M. E.|title=The International Congress on Moral Education|journal=International Journal of Ethics|date=January 1909|volume=19|issue=2|pages=158|publisher=JSTOR|format=Public domain|jstor=2376694|doi=10.1086/206430}}</ref> The first congress was held in 1908,<ref name="1st1908">{{cite book|author=1st International moral education congress|title=Record of the proceedings of the First International Moral Education Congress held at the University of London, September 25-29th, 1908|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iV_OAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA3|edition=Public domain|year=1908|publisher=David Nutt|location=London, England|pages=3–}}</ref> and except for one 10-year beak (1912-1922), the congress met every four years in various cities. The official languages were German, English, and French.<ref name=unige.ch>{{cite web|title=Sources and general information about selected international congresses - Appendix n°2|url=http://www.unige.ch/fapse/SSE/erhise/pdf/Appendix2ESHHS01.pdf|publisher=Université de Genève|accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref>
==Background== The Moral Education League of London was founded in 1897. This organization exercised a considerable influence, not only in the United Kingdom but in various parts of the British Empire and throughout the world. Its president was [[John Stuart Mackenzie]]. Among its members were Catholics, Anglicans, Jews, Unitarians, Hindus, Muslims, Buddhists, Nonconformists, Ethicists, Rationalists, Positivists, and others. Its secretary was Harrold Johnson, who was later appointed Hon. Secretary of the International Moral Education Congress Executive Council. The league also employed a demonstrator, [[Frederick James Gould]], who acquired an international reputation for his numerous books on moral lessons. This League succeeded in 1906 in inducing the Board of Education to make provision for moral instruction in the education code for England and Wales.<ref name=Aikins1913>{{cite web|last1=Aikins|first1=J.A.M.|title=Report on the second International Moral Education Congress at The Hague, August, 1912 and as related thereto moral instruction in the Canadian public schools|url=https://openlibrary.org/books/OL7062408M/Report_on_the_second_International_Moral_Education_Congress_at_The_Hague_August_1912|location=Ottawa|pages=3-|year=1913}}</ref>
In 1905, a new Italian Education Code was published, laying the utmost stress on moral education and making detailed regulations with regard to moral instruction. In the following year, a new Hungarian Education Code was issued. In 1905, a new Austrian Education Code came to light. In Portugal, a manual of Moral Instruction for Primary Schools, as distinct from Religious Instruction, was officially published in 1906. In the United States, schemes of moral instruction were elaborated in many places. In Germany, the Reading Books for Elementary Schools contained abundance of ethical matter. In Switzerland, several Cantons took distinct steps in the direction of drawing up Moral Instruction Programmes. In Belgium, Moral Instruction Syllabuses for Primary Schools and for Training Colleges existed. In France and Japan, where moral instruction was introduced, the subject was being studied with redoubled interest. In Russia, the authorities were turning their attention to this subject. And, finally, in England, the Code of the Board of Education for 1906 stated that "Moral instruction should form an important part of every school curriculum". Educationists generally laid increasing emphasis on the moral factor in education, while men in every walk of life came more and more to feel that the training of the intellect must be accompanied by the development of character if the school is to serve effectively the nation and humanity. This movement for moral education had an ardent champion in the [[Ethical movement]].<ref name=1st1908 />
==1908== [[File:Sir Michael Ernest Sadler photo by George Charles Beresford 1914.jpg|thumbnail|Sir Michael Ernest Sadler, president of the First Congress]] The First Congress was held at the [[University of London]], London, England, on September 25–29, 1908.<ref name=archive.org1st>{{cite web|author1=International Moral Education Congress|author2=Spiller, Gustav|title=Papers on moral education, communicated to the first International Moral Education Congress held at the University of London September 25-29, 1908; (1908)|url=https://archive.org/details/cu31924030610954|publisher=Cornell University Library|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref> [[Michael Sadler (educationist)|Michael Sadler]] served as president. The Congress counted altogether some 1,800 members and 2,000 volumes of the Papers on Moral Education were disposed of within less than four weeks after the first Congress met.<ref name=1st1908 /> Both the educational magazines and the leading daily papers rendered valuable assistance to the Congress. There were sessions on the following topics: The Principles of Moral Education; Aims, Means and Limitations in the various types of schools; Character Building by Discipline, Influence and Opportunity; the Problems of Moral Instruction; Relation of Religious Education to Moral Education; Systematic Moral Instruction; The Relation of Moral Education to Education under Other Aspects; the Problem of Moral Education under varying conditions of Age and Opportunity; Biology and Moral Education.<ref name=Aikins1913 />
==1912== The Second Congress was held at the Hague, August 22–27, 1912.<ref name=archive.org2nd>{{cite web|author1=International Moral Education Congress|author2=Aikins, James Albert Manning|title=Report on the second International Moral Education Congress at The Hague, August, 1912, and as related thereto moral instruction in the Canadian public schools (1913)|url=https://archive.org/details/reportonthesecon00unknuoft|publisher=University of Toronto Libraries|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref> Dr. J. Th. Mouton was the President of the Executive Committee.<ref name="The1912">{{cite book|title=British Books|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2VUwAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA488|edition=Public domain|year=1912|publisher=The Publisher's Circular Limited|pages=488–}}</ref> The following twenty-three countries sent official government delegates: Belgium, Bulgaria, Canada, Chili, China, Denmark, Egypt, France, Greece, Haiti, Hungary, India (British), Ireland, Japan, Norway, Portugal, Russia, Romania, South Australia, Spain, Sweden, Turkey and Tunis. Over 1,000 members (apart from honorary members) were officially enrolled for the congress. Over 200 papers of some 2,000 words each were contributed and appeared in the five published volumes of more than 1,200 pages. The subjects dealt with and under discussion at the various sessions were: Moral Education and Character Building considered from the Denominationalist, the Undenominationalist and the Independent-Moralist points of view; Moral Education considered from social and national points of view Formation of the Will; Physical Training as a means of Character-Building; Moral Education considered from a Practical Point of View; the Moral Education of Adolescents; Character-Building in family life and in society at large; Character-Building of young people at educational institutions not dedicated to the ordinary primary education; Character-Building of Abnormal Children. This Congress stated it would not advocate the views of any society or party, but it would afford to all who are interested in moral education, whatever their religious or ethical convictions, nationality and point of view, an equal opportunity of expressing their opinions and comparing them with those of others. This proved so good a basis that the congress with unanimity adopted it as the basis of future congresses, with the addition of the following object: The object of the Congress is to enlist the active co-operation of all, irrespective of race, nations, and creed, in promoting the work of moral education. The first aim of the Second Congress, as of the first, was to cultivate the co-operation of men and women representing different schools of thought in matters of education, giving every one an opportunity in the spirit of toleration, of defining and explaining his opinion and point of view.<ref name=Aikins1913 />
==1922== [[File:AdolpheFerriereND.jpg|thumbnail|Adolphe Ferriere, president of the Third Congress]] The Third Congress met in the Aula, or Assembly Hall, of the [[University of Geneva]], July 28 to August 1, 1922.<ref name=archive.org3rd>{{cite web|title=International Moral Education Congress|publisher=JSTOR|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-2377499/2377499_djvu.txt}}</ref> About 500 members attended, representing 30 nationalities and 29 national committees. Thirty-three papers were contributed, all being published in French, in two volumes, by Delachaux, at Neuchatel. The topics were confined to (1) the international motive, with special reference to the teaching of history; and (2) the motive of service. [[Sir Frederick Pollock, 3rd Baronet|Frederick Pollock]] gave the inaugural address on behalf of the International Executive Council (London), and was followed by the newly elected president of the Congress, Dr. [[Adolphe Ferrière]], who was an advocate of [[progressive education]]. Among the speakers during the eight sessions, perhaps the most popular were three—Professor Foerster; [[Albert Thomas (minister)|M. Albert Thomas]], Director of the Labor Office of the League of Nations; and [[Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell|Robert Baden-Powell]], the founder of the Scout Movement. A special session was held in the hall of the Secretariat of the League of Nations, chaired by [[Gustav Spiller]], which included [[Nitobe Inazō]], Director of the Section of International Bureaus. The Congress approved of the establishment of an International Moral Education Bureau at the Hague, and decided to form a permanent association of educationists of the world, based on the 29 national committees already existing.<ref name="National1921">{{cite book|author=National Education Association of the United States|title=Today's Education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t2IVAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA316|edition=Public domain|year=1921|publisher=National Education Association|pages=316–}}</ref>
==1926== The Fourth Congress took place in [[Rome]], Italy, from September 28 to October 2, 1926. Francesco Orestano served as president.<ref name="League1925">{{cite book|title=Quarterly Bulletin of Information on the Work of International Organisations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bV8oAQAAMAAJ|year=1925|publisher=League of Nations|page=640}}</ref>
==1930== The Fifth Congress took place at the [[University of Sorbonne]] in Paris, France, September 23–27, 1930.<ref name="League1930">{{cite book|author=League of Nations|title=Quarterly Bulletin of Information on the Work of International Organisations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3V8oAQAAMAAJ|year=1930|publisher=League of Nations|pages=37–38}}</ref><ref name="Watts1930">{{cite book|title=International Moral Education Congress ... Secretary's Report on the fifth Congress at the Sorbonne University, Paris ... 1930|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YQX-oAEACAAJ|year=1930|publisher=C. A. Watts & Company}}</ref> [[Sébastien Charléty]] served as president.
==1934== The Sixth Congress took place in [[Krakow]], Poland, September 11–14, 1934.<ref name="Character1935">{{cite book|title=Proceedings of the Sixth International Moral Education Congress, 1934, Krakow, Poland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8f7gHAAACAAJ|year=1935|publisher=Character Research Service}}</ref>
==Scholarly review== In 2004, Marco Cicchini of the University of Geneva published his study based on a review of the proceedings and publications of the six congresses. He synthesized the congresses' aims and ideals, the theoretical and institutional outlines, the socio-professional profiles of the participants, the status of their contributions, and the disciplines invited to discuss the issues. He also noted on the changes which led to the disappearance of the congress.<ref name=Paedagogica2004>{{cite journal|title=Un bouillon de culture pour les sciences de l'éducation? Le Congrès international d'éducation morale (1908–1934)|journal=Paedagogica Historica|date=2004|volume=40|issue=5-6|pages=633–656|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/0030923042000293698#preview|accessdate=20 August 2014|language=French|format=Paid subscription|doi=10.1080/0030923042000293698}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=International Moral Education Congresses (1908-1934) Marco Cicchini, University of Geneva|url=http://www.unige.ch/fapse/SSE/erhise/ECER2002.html|publisher=University of Geneve|accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref>
==References== *{{Source-attribution|National Education Association of the United States' "Today's Education" (1921)}} *{{Source-attribution|J. A. M. Aikins' "Report on the second International Moral Education Congress at The Hague, August, 1912, and as related thereto moral instruction in the Canadian public schools " (1913)}} *{{Source-attribution|1st International moral education congress's "Record of the proceedings of the First International Moral Education Congress held at the University of London, September 25-29th, 1908" (1908)}} {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
[[Category:1908 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Academic conferences]] [[Category:Morality]] [[Category:Education in Europe]] [[Category:1908 in London]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Use British English|date=August 2014}} {{Unreferenced|date=January 2008}} '''Ivan Vaughan''' (18 June 1942 – 16 August 1993) was a boyhood friend of [[John Lennon]], and later schoolmate of [[Paul McCartney]] at the [[Liverpool Institute]], both commencing school there in September 1953. He was born on the same day as McCartney in [[Liverpool]]. He played [[bass guitar|bass]] part-time in Lennon's first band, The [[Quarrymen]], and was responsible for introducing Lennon to McCartney at a community event (the [[Woolton]] village fête) on 6 July 1957, where The Quarrymen were performing. McCartney impressed Lennon, who invited McCartney to join the band, which he did a day later. This led to the formation of [[Lennon–McCartney|Lennon and McCartney's songwriting partnership]], and later of [[The Beatles]].
==Personal life == Vaughan studied [[Classics]] at [[University College, London]], married in 1966 and settled down to family life with a son and daughter, and became a teacher.
Lennon and McCartney never forgot the friend who brought them together. For a time they put Vaughan on the payroll of their Apple company, in charge of a plan that never took off to set up a school with a Sixties, hippie-style education ethos. Vaughan's wife Jan, a language teacher, was hired to sit down with Lennon and McCartney and help with the French lyrics to the 1965 song "[[Michelle (song)|Michelle]]".
==Autobiographic and Documentary == In 1977 Vaughan was diagnosed with [[Parkinson's Disease]]. His book, ''Ivan: Living with Parkinson’s Disease'' was published in 1986 and he also featured in a documentary produced for the BBC in 1984 by [[Jonathan Miller]] about his search for a cure.
Vaughan's death touched Paul McCartney so deeply that he began to write poetry for the first time since he was a child. He wrote the poem "Ivan" about him after his death, which was published in McCartney's book, ''Blackbird Singing''.
{{Ex-members of the Beatles and the Quarrymen}} {{Authority control}}
